questions.text: What is the most common cause of Cushing’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of Cushing’s syndrome is iatrogenic due to administration of corticosteroids.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following causes ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Cushing’s disease causes ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome. It occurs due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Cushing's syndrome?

choices.text: It is commonly associated with MEN1 syndrome
Bronchial carcinoid is a possible cause
It is associated with coronary heart disease

questions.solution:
Cushing’s syndrome is rarely associated with MEN1 syndrome.

Bronchial carcinoids are a source of ectopic ACTH secretion resulting in ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome.

Clinical features of Cushing’s syndrome are attributed to the glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and sex steroid actions of cortisol. They include:

System Clinical features
Body fat
  • Central or truncal obesity (most common)
  • Buffalo hump (fat deposition behind the neck)
  • Moon facies  
Skin
  • Purple striae (over abdomen & flanks)
  • Acne and Hirsutism 
  • Easy bruising 
  • Facial plethora
  • Hyperpigmentation 
Musculoskeletal
  • Proximal myopathy
  • Osteoporosis
Metabolic
  • Poorly controlled hyperglycemia
  • Dyslipidemia
Reproductive
  • Oligomenorrhea
  • Amenorrhea
Renal
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
CVS
  • Atherosclerosis 
  • Diastolic Hypertension 
  • Edema 
Hematologic
  • Hypercoagulable state 
  • Lymphopenia
  • Neutrophilia
  • Eosinopenia
CNS
  • Depression
  • Psychosis 
  • Anxiety

questions.text: A patient with Cushing's syndrome is least likely to present with:
questions.solution:
Proximal myopathy is commonly seen in Cushing’s syndrome, not distal myopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following would not be seen in a patient with Cushing’s disease?
questions.solution:
Cushing’s disease, and all other causes of Cushing's syndrome, can result in a hypercoagulable state. This is due to an increase in procoagulant factors and inhibition of fibrinolysis.

Cushing's disease is a form of Cushing's syndrome caused by an ACTH-secreting pituitary tumor. The high ACTH levels stimulate melanocytes and cause skin hyperpigmentation. This is especially seen over friction-prone areas like knuckles and elbows.

The majority of patients with Cushing's syndrome have psychiatric symptoms such as:

  • Anxiety,
  • Depression, and
  • Frank psychosis  

Mineralocorticoid action of cortisol may lead to diastolic hypertension, hypokalemia, and edema.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman visits a gynecologist with complaints of irregular and infrequent menstrual cycles. She is also upset that she has gained 12 kg over the past few months. Her face appears as shown in the image below. Her blood pressure at this visit is 144/98 mm Hg and she has multiple purple striae over her abdomen. Which of the following investigations should you advise this patient?

choices.text: Serum testosterone levels and abdominal USG

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing moon facies with acne and hirsutism are suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome. It can be diagnosed with the help of a single midnight serum cortisol measurement.

Option A: Cosyntropin (ACTH) stimulation test is used for the diagnosis of Addison's disease.

Options C and D: Serum testosterone, abdominal USG, and LH: FSH ratio, are used to confirm a diagnosis of the polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Though PCOS can present with similar features, it is not typically associated with moon facies, purple striae, or hypertension.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: You can advise any of the following tests for screening of a patient suspected to be having Cushing's syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Determination of plasma ACTH levels is not advised as a screening test for a patient with Cushing's syndrome.

Plasma ACTH determination is done to distinguish between ACTH-dependent and independent causes. It is done after the screening or confirmation of Cushing's syndrome.

questions.text: In patients with which of the following conditions would you expect to see the highest basal ACTH level?
questions.solution:
Basal plasma ACTH levels are highest in ectopic ACTH-secreting tumors.

Plasma ACTH > 15pg/ml is suggestive of ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome due to pituitary or ectopic sources. Basal ACTH in pituitary adenoma can be normal or elevated, whereas in an ectopic source the ACTH production is very high. This occurs because a pituitary adenoma retains some sensitivity to the negative feedback mechanism exerted by cortisol, but ectopic tumors remain unaffected. 

Plasma ACTH < 5pg/ml is suggestive of ACTH-independent Cushing’s syndrome that can be caused by an adrenal adenoma or exogenous administration of glucocorticoids.

questions.text: A patient with suspected Cushing's syndrome is found to have elevated ACTH levels. What is the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
An elevated ACTH level is suggestive of ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome. The investigation of choice for ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome is MRI brain, to look for the presence of a pituitary tumour.

If the MRI brain shows a mass it is suggestive of a pituitary mass of >6 mm in size. However, if the MRI brain does not show a mass it suggests a pituitary tumor of <6mm in size or an ectopic ACTH source.

Note: High-dose dexamethasone suppression test and CRH stimulation test are employed to differentiate pituitary from ectopic ACTH syndrome. A definitive cause can be established only by imaging techniques like MRI for pituitary tumors, CT scan of the chest and abdomen for ectopic ACTH sites. Hence MRI is considered the investigation of choice.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man chronic smoker presented with flecks of blood in his sputum. He is currently on treatment for COPD and hypertension. His BMI is 31 kg/m² and he has central obesity. His RBS is 261 mg/dl. During further evaluation, he is found to have high ACTH levels that remained high even after administration of high-dose dexamethasone. What is the underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Elevated ACTH levels that do not get suppressed by a high-dose dexamethasone test are suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome secondary to an ectopic ACTH-secreting tumor. Considering the patient's smoking history and presentation with hemoptysis, it is likely to be a lung tumor.

Dynamic testing for Cushing’s syndrome
  High dose dexamethasone suppression test CRH stimulation test
Pituitary adenoma Positive (suppressed cortisol) Positive (increase in ACTH and cortisol)
Ectopic ACTH Negative Negative
Iatrogenic: Suppressed ACTH levels that are not affected by dynamic testing
Adrenal mass or hyperplasia:  Suppressed ACTH levels that are not affected by dynamic testing

Ectopic sources of ACTH include small cell lung cancers and pulmonary carcinoid tumors. The most effective treatment strategy is the management of the underlying SCLC or carcinoid.

questions.text: Evaluation of a patient with Cushing's syndrome reveals high ACTH levels that are responsive to CRH and suppressed by high-dose dexamethasone. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CRH responsiveness is seen only in ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism which is due to a pituitary cause. This is because the pituitary tumor contains corticotrophic cells that are responsive to CRH.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was diagnosed with ACTH-dependent Cushing's syndrome. As MRI of the pituitary was normal and further testing was unequivocal, she was scheduled for inferior petrosal sinus sampling. It revealed a baseline petrosal:peripheral ACTH ratio > 2. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Cushing’s syndrome with petrosal: peripheral ACTH ratio > 2 at baseline confirms the presence of an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. The treatment of choice is transsphenoidal pituitary surgery. Radiotherapy is used in case of recurrence of tumors.

Inferior petrosal sinus sampling is performed to differentiate pituitary and ectopic sources of ACTH when initial imaging and testing are inconclusive.

questions.text: Which of the following would not be used to treat patients with Cushing’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Mitomycin is not used in the treatment of Cushing’s syndrome. The drugs used in its management include:

  • Metyrapone
  • Ketoconazole
  • Aminoglutethimide
  • Trilostane
  • Cyproheptadine
  • Mitotane – Mainly in adrenal carcinoma
  • Etomidate – Severe cortisol excess

questions.text: Which of the following is the best adrenolytic agent that can be used in the management of patients with adrenocortical carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Mitotane is used in the management of adrenocortical carcinoma due to its adrenolytic properties.

Mitotane is an insecticide derivative. It is effective in the treatment of benign Cushing's also, but is rarely used due to its side effects.

questions.text: Which of the following complications is associated with bilateral adrenalectomy?
questions.solution:
Nelson’s syndrome is a rare complication of total bilateral adrenalectomy (TBA). TBA is a procedure used to control hypercortisolism in Cushing's disease (due to ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) when resection of the primary tumor is not possible.

The loss of feedback inhibition of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis following TBA increases CRH. This leads to stimulation of ACTH-secreting corticotroph cells, causing enlargement of the original pituitary tumor or the formation of a new one.

Nelson's syndrome is associated with a clinical triad of:

  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Excessive ACTH secretion
  • Corticotroph adenoma

Screening is done with fasting plasma ACTH levels and MRI brain is performed at regular intervals. Prophylactic pituitary irradiation may be recommended to prevent its incidence. The primary treatment is transsphenoidal surgery. Patients will also require life-long glucocorticoid replacement, as they do not produce cortisol.

The use of steroidogenic inhibitors in the treatment of Cushing's disease has decreased the need for bilateral adrenalectomy these days.

Option A: Sheehan’s syndrome refers to postpartum hypopituitarism that is caused by ischemic necrosis of the anterior pituitary as a result of severe postpartum hemorrhage.

Option B: Addison's disease occurs due to autoimmune destruction of adrenal glands.

Option C: Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome refers to adrenal apoplexy that is caused by fulminant meningococcemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of pseudo-Cushing's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Malignancy does not cause pseudo-Cushing's syndrome. It may cause ectopic ACTH production, leading to true Cushing’s syndrome.

Pseudo-Cushing’s syndrome refers to functional hypercortisolism caused by chronic activation of the HPA axis. It presents with clinical and biochemical features similar to Cushing’s syndrome, making it difficult to differentiate between them. It may occur secondary to the following conditions: 

  • Severe major depressive disorder
  • Polycystic ovarian syndrome
  • Insulin-resistant obesity
  • Obstructive sleep apnea
  • Chronic alcoholism
  • End-stage renal disease

It usually resolves when the underlying condition is treated.
